content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												A visually pleasing vertical-scrolling shooter. Touhou-reminiscent dodging and bullet density with a whimsical retro-futuristic art style that reminds me a bit of Metal Slug.  The enemies behave like Raiden or Tyrian, coming from all angles or out of the scenery, but the bullets behave like Touhou, killing you in one shot if they come into contact with your small hitbox, located in the center of your character sprite.  This game has several difficulty levels to cater to any tier of gamer. Another surprise was the novel and intuitive scoring system. This is a gem of its genre and deserves your attention.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2011
												Now here's a good indie game. Jamestown is a top-down shooter (such as 19XX) with the odd plot of being a convict on the lamb trying to redeem your name in the new world. The year is 1619, and the new world happens to be Mars.You battle your way through Martian and Spanish forces and uncover a diabolical plot all in the safety of the cutscenes. The rest of the time you're blowing your way through anything that gets in your way.The 4 ships you have to choose from are a bit limiting, but varied and each useful in their own way. This is also where the game shows it's true awesomeness. If you can get some friends together on the same computer, you can team up with whatever selection of ships you want and blow away the Martians and evil Spanish.A great game, I'd advise it for anyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												While I personally can't compare Jamestown to the entire Touhou Project as I've only played a couple titles from the series, this game is a fantastic bullet-hell shooter on the high difficulties, and an enjoyable vertical shooter on the lower difficulties. It's the most fun I've had since Ikaruga and Gigawing 2. If you're a fan of Raiden, Raptor: Call of the Shadows, or even Gradius, I highly suggest you pick this one up and give it a shot.There are several levels, a couple dozen challenge levels, eight different ships with two firing modes each, and a combo system that encourages skillful movement, positioning, and awareness. If you're a real master at bullet-hell games, I'll admit that Jamestown might be too easy for your liking to get through - but mastering the combo system takes time, patience, and is very rewarding once you can tie together a huge string of hits.It's available in the Humble Indie Bundle 4 if you want more bang for your buck, but it stands alone quite nicely.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												If you are a fan of the bullet hell style shooters such as the Touhou series or the Gundemonium games, then James town is the perfect game for you. I actually like the fact that the final level can only be played on the highest challenge option, it makes things that much more interesting.Then there's the array of Challenge maps that can be played aside from the story it's self. One of the biggest bonuses this game has over others in this same genre is that it supports up to 4 person multi-player. While the graphics are simple they're still visually captivating and hearken back to the SNES days with a 16-bit reminiscent style.  The music is well picked and along with the graphics provide the right atmosphere for this game. I say if you like bullet hell style shooters play this game, and I feel this is also a good place for people new this type of game to start with it's progressing difficulty that allows you to work up to final boss.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Steam logs ~2 hours to my playtime, and a significant portion of that played with my 6-year-old in co-op, so it's not terribly long, but does provide a challenge (it was more difficult with a child weighing me down).  Jamestown is... fine. It's a bullet-hell shmup. If you like that kind of thing and want to be a perfectionist at it, then Jamestown gives you the venue. The story is unusual - a colonial era story but for some reason set on Mars instead of the American colonies, but with all the heroes and villains of the colonial era. Other than that, there's some bonus stage unlocks and some advanced difficulty options. So yeah.  4 player co-op bullet-hell shmup. You kinda know if this kind of this is for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												This is the best game I ever got by accident. It was part of a humble bundle that I bought just for the game Closure, and had no intention of playing Jamestown. Ironically, I ended up playing Closure for all of 20 minutes, and I've invested nearly 10 hours into this one.I rarely even play shooters, and yet this game is thoroughly addicting and enjoyable. What I like most is the simplicity. It takes 5 minutes to learn everything there is to know about how to play, and you can jump right in on the lowest difficulty and have some fun without getting crushed right away. The difficulty scales very well, and each stage requires you to beat all the previous stages on a higher difficulty level than the one before to unlock the next stage. It's a natural progression, and is suitable even for someone like myself who isn't a veteran to these types of games. That being said, there are only five stages in the game which are each very short, but they are well designed and have high replay value. On top of that there are five challenge packs that you can purchase using in game currency, which range from challenging to rage inducing.But what really makes this game most enjoyable are the beautiful 16-bit sprites and the art direction. A high level of detail was put into each stage, and some of the backgrounds are gorgeous. It's only too bad you don't have much time to look at them as you're constantly dodging bullets. It's got that classic old school look but at the same time has an aesthetic all its own. Plus the explosions look great, and I love how you collect gold from each enemy you destroy. Each time you blow up a ship and those chunks of gold pieces come falling down the screen, it's a real treat and feels so rewarding. Oh, and the soundtrack is awesome too.All in all, if you're a fan of schmup games, this is a must buy. I paid practically nothing for it, but can say it's easily worth 10 bucks. And if you can get it on sale ($4.99 when I wrote this) then it's a no brainer.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2012
												Believe it or not, Jamestown is a Bullet Hell game that isn't completely about Bullet Hell. Jamestown is a beautiful top-down arcade SHMUP that can be picked up and played by anyone, a casual gamer or a Touhou veteran. There are five different difficulty levels with each level adding more and more bullets that can riddle your ship (but not kill you unless it hits the middle). The downside if you're a casual player is that you only have three levels, the other three levels require you to be playing on the harder difficulties, cutting the experience in half.If you're willing to put your neck out there and aim for the skies, Jamestown is an experience you'd be foolish to pass up.If you aren't willing, well, the game's still pretty damn awesome.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2012
												Although it looks daunting from previews, Jamestown offers a solid bullet hell shump. This game is well crafted in and out, giving a great experience even to those not so accustomed to bullet hell, like me. The story is an alternate history of the real Jamestown set on Mars with aliens along with the period rivarly between Britain and Spain. Steampunk rules the time as complex machinery and shooting ships are used. The art is in pixel art, supporting the story and giving a special style to the game. Music is a mix of orchestra and rock and some synths, providing for a kick♥♥♥♥♥theme when playing. These 3 are all solidly made. Difficulty starts at a low level, but the game ramps it up on later levels and forces revisiting older levels on a higher difficulty. By the last level, the game is really tough but memorizing and dodging is key. The game is short, I got 2 hrs for the main story but it gave a great experience and challenge. Bonuses keep players back for more.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												A visually pleasing vertical-scrolling shooter. Touhou-reminiscent dodging and bullet density with a whimsical retro-futuristic art style that reminds me a bit of Metal Slug.  The enemies behave like Raiden or Tyrian, coming from all angles or out of the scenery, but the bullets behave like Touhou, killing you in one shot if they come into contact with your small hitbox, located in the center of your character sprite.  This game has several difficulty levels to cater to any tier of gamer. Another surprise was the novel and intuitive scoring system. This is a gem of its genre and deserves your attention.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2011
												Now here's a good indie game. Jamestown is a top-down shooter (such as 19XX) with the odd plot of being a convict on the lamb trying to redeem your name in the new world. The year is 1619, and the new world happens to be Mars.You battle your way through Martian and Spanish forces and uncover a diabolical plot all in the safety of the cutscenes. The rest of the time you're blowing your way through anything that gets in your way.The 4 ships you have to choose from are a bit limiting, but varied and each useful in their own way. This is also where the game shows it's true awesomeness. If you can get some friends together on the same computer, you can team up with whatever selection of ships you want and blow away the Martians and evil Spanish.A great game, I'd advise it for anyone.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												While I personally can't compare Jamestown to the entire Touhou Project as I've only played a couple titles from the series, this game is a fantastic bullet-hell shooter on the high difficulties, and an enjoyable vertical shooter on the lower difficulties. It's the most fun I've had since Ikaruga and Gigawing 2. If you're a fan of Raiden, Raptor: Call of the Shadows, or even Gradius, I highly suggest you pick this one up and give it a shot.There are several levels, a couple dozen challenge levels, eight different ships with two firing modes each, and a combo system that encourages skillful movement, positioning, and awareness. If you're a real master at bullet-hell games, I'll admit that Jamestown might be too easy for your liking to get through - but mastering the combo system takes time, patience, and is very rewarding once you can tie together a huge string of hits.It's available in the Humble Indie Bundle 4 if you want more bang for your buck, but it stands alone quite nicely.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												This is the best game I ever got by accident. It was part of a humble bundle that I bought just for the game Closure, and had no intention of playing Jamestown. Ironically, I ended up playing Closure for all of 20 minutes, and I've invested nearly 10 hours into this one.I rarely even play shooters, and yet this game is thoroughly addicting and enjoyable. What I like most is the simplicity. It takes 5 minutes to learn everything there is to know about how to play, and you can jump right in on the lowest difficulty and have some fun without getting crushed right away. The difficulty scales very well, and each stage requires you to beat all the previous stages on a higher difficulty level than the one before to unlock the next stage. It's a natural progression, and is suitable even for someone like myself who isn't a veteran to these types of games. That being said, there are only five stages in the game which are each very short, but they are well designed and have high replay value. On top of that there are five challenge packs that you can purchase using in game currency, which range from challenging to rage inducing.But what really makes this game most enjoyable are the beautiful 16-bit sprites and the art direction. A high level of detail was put into each stage, and some of the backgrounds are gorgeous. It's only too bad you don't have much time to look at them as you're constantly dodging bullets. It's got that classic old school look but at the same time has an aesthetic all its own. Plus the explosions look great, and I love how you collect gold from each enemy you destroy. Each time you blow up a ship and those chunks of gold pieces come falling down the screen, it's a real treat and feels so rewarding. Oh, and the soundtrack is awesome too.All in all, if you're a fan of schmup games, this is a must buy. I paid practically nothing for it, but can say it's easily worth 10 bucks. And if you can get it on sale ($4.99 when I wrote this) then it's a no brainer.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2013
												Fans of top-down shmups (shoot 'em ups) need look no further than Jamestown. While not quite as punishing as the Japanese variety in this genre, the difficulty scales up intelligently and the game eases you into the action. In order to progress farther in the game you have to get better and the game helps you get better by forcing you to play higher difficulty levels as you progress through the game. It sounds cheap, but in games like this it's way too easy to keep the difficulty low and storm through the game. The way the game progresses will show you (even those unfamiliar with the genre) how good you can be at dodging through a screenful of glowing lazers and suicidal enemy ships. Online and local multiplayer, challenges, and a quirky "farce" mode makes this game great to play if you have extra time here and there.

Posted: December 15, 2012
												Absolutely great bullet hell game. Pilot a ship--wreck everything.Jamestown runs very smoothly and poses a nice challenge to those newer to the genre. The enemies are fun to kill and defeating bosses provides tons of extra gratification. If the main story wasn't enough, there are five difficulty levels for each world, a continuous gauntlet mode, and challenge levels for extra hours of play time. Bomber and Gunner ships add a whole new difficult level as well.Then, if you have some friends who want to play--there's multiplayer!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2012
												Jamestown is an old school bullet hell arcade shooter, but with 4 player co-op. In that regard already it's quite unique and interesting. The only way to make bullet hell games more visually chaotic is the addition of more players. But what makes Jamestown more interesting is it's setting, story, and presentation. It's basicly a sci-fi steam-punk neo-classical retelling of the early days of the English American colonies. You face the forces of the Martian/Spanish alliance in hopes of being pardoned for a crime against the English crown. The orchestral soundtrack and story scenes somehow make this seem more epic than you expect, even if it is a bit silly. And the entire package feels polished and well made. There are unlockables and bonus missions to keep dragging you back, even if it is a short game; and there're always high scores to be challenged. One of my favourite bullet-hell games ever.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												Bullet-Hell At It's FinestI'm a sucker for pixels, games that make me want to punch a wall (if well made, not due to blatantly shoddy construction... i'm describing the games... not the wall), and fiction loosely based on actual events. Jamestown quenches all of these thirsts along with an unexpectedly stunning soundtrack to create a wonderful shooter for both the novice and the masochistic.This top-down arcade sci-fi shmup is all about style. Difficulties can be chosen before each stage, ranging from the easiest resembling 1942 to Insane which will challenge any fan of the Touhou series. (If you don't know touhou, find it on youtube and it will make your eyes bleed. In a good way.)Multiple ships (with more available via DLC!), a wide array of difficulties, and an in-game unlockables via gold gained for blowing things up and creating long bonus string allow for many return plays, for both quick breaks or marathon sessions.One downside - The 4-player Coop is SINGLE MACHINE ONLY. There is no online option. It's great for having a few people together, but in this day and age, not having online multiplayer can really limit popularity of a title. But... THAT'S IT! Everything else is a big thumbs up.It's even got an unlockable "parody" mode. Doesn't change much, but it really adds a lovely transparency to the developers' love of oldschool shooters.This is a shining example of what the indie game scene can do. Do yourself a favor and pick this beast up.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2011
												If you like bullet-hell games such as Touhou, Ikaruga, DoDonPachi, Radiant Silvergun, etc. then there shouldn't be a reason why you wouldn't like this one.  The game features an addictive point system and has some nifty features to make you keep playing for a while.  Trying to get higher in the leaderboards is always a fun thing.  The game is difficult as this genre is known for so it isn't for the casual player.  Although, the game does feature multiple difficulty levels to allow players for some practice if you are new to the genre.  Besides, 10 bucks isn't a bad deal.  I will say that the story is very odd, which shouldn't be surprising as most of these shooters have off-the-wall story lines and aren't really story driven anyway.  Just go in and enjoy trying to post some high scores..

content:
Posted: April 13, 2012
												Believe it or not, Jamestown is a Bullet Hell game that isn't completely about Bullet Hell. Jamestown is a beautiful top-down arcade SHMUP that can be picked up and played by anyone, a casual gamer or a Touhou veteran. There are five different difficulty levels with each level adding more and more bullets that can riddle your ship (but not kill you unless it hits the middle). The downside if you're a casual player is that you only have three levels, the other three levels require you to be playing on the harder difficulties, cutting the experience in half.If you're willing to put your neck out there and aim for the skies, Jamestown is an experience you'd be foolish to pass up.If you aren't willing, well, the game's still pretty damn awesome.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2013
												Fans of top-down shmups (shoot 'em ups) need look no further than Jamestown. While not quite as punishing as the Japanese variety in this genre, the difficulty scales up intelligently and the game eases you into the action. In order to progress farther in the game you have to get better and the game helps you get better by forcing you to play higher difficulty levels as you progress through the game. It sounds cheap, but in games like this it's way too easy to keep the difficulty low and storm through the game. The way the game progresses will show you (even those unfamiliar with the genre) how good you can be at dodging through a screenful of glowing lazers and suicidal enemy ships. Online and local multiplayer, challenges, and a quirky "farce" mode makes this game great to play if you have extra time here and there.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2012
												TL;DR:  it's a bullet hell shmup, which is the only deciding factor as to whether you'll like this game.If you dislike flying a widdle ship through a maze of deadly glowing balls, you won't like Jamestown.  But if you're at least open to possibly enjoying such a game, you'll like, even love Jamestown.Its only real flaw is that its premise and story are a bit overdone (Walter Raleigh flees the Spanish in the seventeenth century by escaping to the New World, except the New World is Mars), but the execution is masterful, from the beautiful eight-bit sprites to the solid mechanics to the surprisingly superb soundtrack.There's unlockable challenge strages, multiple ships with different secondary firing modes, a ramping difficulty to keep you improving, and even DLC with three more ships (including a fourth that randomly mimics one of the other seven).  And seriously, that music.  Kinda freakin' awesome.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2012
												Jamestown's story is quite unusual. Imagine the 17th century. The colonization of the New World and all that. This English colony is contested by the Spanish. Who are in league with the Martians. Because everything happens on Mars. And you, Sir Walter Raleigh, must stop them. With your spaceship. How crazy is that?The game itself is of the newly-formed 'bullet hell', a vertically scrolling shoot 'em up genre which emphasises on small Player Character hitboxes and dodging millions of bullets at a time.You can use any of four ships, associated with four historical characters, each with its secondary fire, and a Vaunt Mode, which can be activated after collecting enough gold from your enemies, and gives you a temporary shield which absorbs all bullets, a double damage boost and a double score boost. The difficulty scales up quickly, and the challenge levels add to it even more. In short, Jamestown is one explosive, manic, and hilarious game. Why not give it a try?

content:
Posted: October 20, 2011
												Having just finished this, I felt I should go back and write a proper review. In short it's a bullet hell shooter. If you don't know what that is basically, the enemies fill the screen with bullets and you have to dodge them while trying to rack up a high score.The scoring system is simple but fun. When enemies die they drop gold which, when picked up, fills up your Vaunt meter. When your Vaunt meter is full you can press mouse 3 to activate Vaunt mode. In Vaunt mode a forcefield will appear around you for about 3 seconds that absorbs all bullets it comes into contact with. Your meter will slowly decrease but picking up gold will fill it up again. When Vaunt ends you get bonus points depending on how long you kept the combo going. If you die, it ends the combo and you get nothing.There's 4 person cooperative multiplayer but it's local only, which sucks.This game is challenging but rewarding and the soundtrack is spectacular. 100% recommended!

												Jamestown is a wonderful homage to the genre, up there with Locomalito's Hydorah, and features a setting that quickly became one of my favorites - a 17th century alternate history that repositions "the New World" in the literal sense, while avoiding steampunk cliches. content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												An amazingly well crafted shoot-em-up game which will make you feel like you're back in the SNES era! The game itself is intuitive and easy to pick up and play, yet challenging in its own right. The game offers about five different levels of difficulty (plus Hardcore Mode), which will keep even the most skilled players busy for awhile. Add to that an interesting and well written story, and throw in one of the best soundtracks in gaming and you've got yourself a no-brainer. It's the greatest SNES shoot-em-up never made!

content:
Posted: August 21, 2011
												This is a game were you have to find patterns in the shots being fired at you from the enemy. It has epic music that gets your blood going and action that doesn't stop until the end. It can be a difficult game to get down, but with practice you will understand how to move between the bullets to beat each level. The levels are alot different with a variety of enemy's to shoot and blow up. There is alot to this game with bonus levels and "Gauntlet" mode were you have to beat the game in one sitting and without loosing your cool. There are 4 ships to choose from that really have different style of play.There is a co-op mode were you can play with friends, but not online with other people. The game has old school graphics but new school gameplay. I recommend picking this one up when it ever becomes available at a price that suits you. Its a great casual game that can be very hard to put down.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2012
												Jamestown's story is quite unusual. Imagine the 17th century. The colonization of the New World and all that. This English colony is contested by the Spanish. Who are in league with the Martians. Because everything happens on Mars. And you, Sir Walter Raleigh, must stop them. With your spaceship. How crazy is that?The game itself is of the newly-formed 'bullet hell', a vertically scrolling shoot 'em up genre which emphasises on small Player Character hitboxes and dodging millions of bullets at a time.You can use any of four ships, associated with four historical characters, each with its secondary fire, and a Vaunt Mode, which can be activated after collecting enough gold from your enemies, and gives you a temporary shield which absorbs all bullets, a double damage boost and a double score boost. The difficulty scales up quickly, and the challenge levels add to it even more. In short, Jamestown is one explosive, manic, and hilarious game. Why not give it a try?

												Jamestown is a wonderful homage to the genre, up there with Locomalito's Hydorah, and features a setting that quickly became one of my favorites - a 17th century alternate history that repositions "the New World" in the literal sense, while avoiding steampunk cliches. The music is fantastic, reminding me of the best of PS1 era orchestration in games like Final Fantasy Tactics, the pixel art is pretty much spot on, though a bit messy-seeming in places, and I only wish I had some people here in front of my macbook to play 4P with.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2011
												Jamestown is a top-down arcade-style space shooter like Raiden or Galaga with very beautiful 16-bit-style pixel art and very fun, modern gameplay.I normally really enjoy these sorts of games, and not suprsingly, I enjoyed this one too. Lots of enemies, lots of bullets, and the controls are good enough that you can deal with both. There are five difficulty settings and interesting bonus levels that increase replay value. But, what really made the game fun was the multiplayer.  You can play locally with up to four players, using mouse, keyboard, or gamepads. I hadn't played a good local multiplayer game in a while, and this was a blast with three. There are four different ship types, so people can take on multiple roles in a group. Best to stick with the easiest type if you're going solo, though.I just got it on sale, and it's already been worth the money for me. If you like this sort of game, then I think you'll enjoy this one too.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												A good introduction to bullet hell. Or rather, it was my introduction and I've enjoyed it. The game looks and sounds very good, and has a pretty slick arcade-y interface as a whole. There's only 5 levels, the idea is you replay them on increasing difficulty levels and it works for me. 3 of the 4 available planes feel good and provide fresh gameplay, and the bullet-eating vaunt powerup system is a lot of fun to use. There's a nice difficulty curve from kinda hectic on "normal", to wtf crazy on "divine," and then the highest difficulty, "judgement," just kicks out your crutches and reminds you why its called bullet hell.Oh, and there's multiplayer, but as of yet it's local only, so who knows how that is. They said they'd put netplay in if there was demand, but at the time of writing there's certainly demand but no mention from the devs of working on it. The game can stand on its single player, but netplay would be nice.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2012
												It's a very well done bullet hell, shoot em up game. Easy to pick up, hard to master. There is a vaunt mechanic that provides a temporary relief, and different ships with different abilities so there is a degree of strategy as well while playing. It also has a local multiplayer and can use either the mouse or keyboard so you can easily get 4 people playing on the same computer.  It is challenging and really fun to play with friends so it's definitely worth it. The DLC adds new ships, but my fav is one that comes standard. I haven't tried the hardest difficuly, but I hear that it ramps up the difficulty considerably, so there will always be something to draw your attention.

												This game. Freaking love it. The sound track is great let me first say that. This is a classic top down shooter.You get ship upgrades,boss fights,power ups (each ship comes with a unique power up),unlockable ships, and a world map. The world map has other levels you can unlock to play by getting enough points and reaching certain goals to unlock the bonus material that does not detract from the main campaign at all and serves as a reward for your hard work at accepting th various challenges needed to unlock them.If your a shooter fan, do not miss this. content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Between the large numbers of FPS games, and the RPGs, Bullet Hell shooters are sadly under-represented on Steam, and in fact, in Western gaming in general.Jamestown is one such example of a Bullet Hell shooter. It gives you a variety of ships that you can use to pummel through a variety of enemies, while at the same time trying to avoid getting pummeled yourself. It's very lenient on lives, and the levels are short, so if you can get used to levels one at a time it's not a particularly difficult bullet hell, but it serves its purpose well and is highly recommended if you're a fan of scrolling shooter type games, or perhaps are looking for something in a genre you have not had any chance to play yet.It's very inexpensive, so worth a buy.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												If you're completely mad for bullet hell-style games then this game is definitely for you, so stop reading here, but as a big casual myself i really didn't enjoy it. The shooting generally feels really light and unsatisfying with anemic sound effects, and the three extra ships you can buy are less fun to use than the one you start with. Moreover, the game as of Jan. 2016 is bugged, with all enemy projectiles displayed as grey, which makes the game needlessly hard-- you can fix it by opting in to the Beta version, but who knows what you're missing out on there. The music and the setting are unique and carefully done, but TOO carefully done i think-- i'd rather play a game where the game makers' time was all spent on rock-solid mechanics at the expense of the story than the opposite, and this is the opposite in my own opinion. You really need to have your ducks in a row to spend that much time developing the stylistic elements, but it's not a good enough shooter to get away with it so the whole martian-colonialism thing just ends up being distracting/pointless as you die for the 3000th time to a bullet you couldn't see coming (for a shooter that gets it right see 'Sine Mora', which gets away with its elaborate narrative elements in spades, though admittedly the Arcade mode is pointlessly difficult and rage-inducing). So yeah, as a non-superfan of the genre, i really didn't enjoy this-- it's too bugged and hard and viscerally lacking. I'd dock it further points for having an Infuriatingly Annoying Indoor Level, but then pretty much every shooter has one of those...

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												Jamestown is a work of art. The superb way every attack forces you to calculate Vaunt perfectly, the many varied ships with hunderds of unique designs, everything comes together to make what is certainly the greatest indie game, bullet hell game, and roguelike of 2016.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												In many ways, this is a baby's first bullet hell game.  It's a bullet hell shoot em up that is relatively easy to start, giving you a way to soak up lots of damage and increase your weapons without taking a hit, and it has several different types of ships and weapons for different play styles.  This game's graphics are just gorgeous, from the wonderfully alien martians and monstrous enemies you fight in search of roanoke, to the steam punk ships and bosses.  It's a beautiful amalgam of sprites and pixel art.  What surprised me most is the sound track, honestly.  It's soul stirring in places, particularly the final boss.  I was getting a Final Fantasy 7, Sephiroth vibe of it.  And the difficulty sliders make the game more akin to a true bullet hell the harder you go, so there's something here for all ages, especially with the challenge maps.  Frustratingly, the game only gives you a set number of lives in single player...I wish they gave you one ups based on your score.  That would have made this game perfect.  Otherwise, this is a super fun shmup that anyone can get into.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2012
												Jamestown is just a really great game all around. I am surprised it is Final Form Games's first game; what a debut. It's a vertically-scrolling bullet hell shoot-em-up with a well-presented story, which is about the first colony Jamestown, and it has conquistadors and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Except this Jamestown is on Mars! You play as Sir Walter Raleigh on a spaceship, and what you do is fire all sorts of lasers at all those Spanish Martian ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. There are 4 ships to choose from, with 3 more from a downloadable expansion, and each ship has 2 firing modes. One of my favorite things about this game is local co-op of up two 4 players, all on one computer! You can have one person on mouse, one on keyboard, one on joystick, and one on gamepad, or whatever other alternative input devices. I like the overall feel of this game and the pixelly artstyle and the menus and the music is really outstanding too. There's also a bunch of different difficulties to play on, and bonus levels and lots of  unlockables.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Bullet hell is an understatement. Prepare to have 1000 things on the screen at once all trying to kill you. Its amazing! The controls are tight and every death feels a mistake on the player, not an unfair circumstance. In order to beat the story mode you will have to be able to beat all of the levels of legendary, but the game offers even higher difficulties and challenge modes that will make you cry blood with frustration. The replayability is fantastic.This game is beautiful. The graphics are nostalgic and the artwork does a good job of establishing its own style. The sound is also really good, I found myself getting caught up in the music while playing, it fits the scenario really well.If the gameplay looks appealing to you, then this game is a must buy, very well executed and very fun to play!

												TL;DR: All my recommend thumb, all of it. At once.Real Review: I absolutely recommend this game to fans of vertical shooters and bullet hells. It's a solid challenge and everything is done right. 8 possible ships to choose from, the soundtrack is AMAZING by itself, the pixel art is great. Everything.  5 levels with 5 modes of difficulty, a gauntlet mode, challenge levels. There is enough content here that will keep you busy for a while. It's an added bonus that the achievements list has some achievements that really make you work for it. Definitely belongs in your library. Hell, it belongs...in your heart.Oh, and you can play with 3 others too with local co-op, if that is what you are into. You have spent too long reading this and not playing it. Go buy it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is a brilliantly designed and produced top-down shooter. The retro graphics and soundtrack is charming, the plot melds Victorian-era events with sci-fi and steam punk. The combination makes for a really intriguing mix.This is a skill-based game and the tight controls and unique ship designs/weapon systems will give you countless hours of enjoyment and frustration. If you die, it's probably your fault. Thankfully, the learning curve is handled well i.e. you can't try more difficult levels until you've managed to beat the previous levels at a certain difficulty.This is a relatively short game depending on how good you are able to master the ships and become one with the controls. I find myself favoring the game pad though a keyboard + mouse also works well. Multi-player coop is also quite fun.The charm of this game is that it can also be played in small doses. There was a time that I couldn't beat the final boss. For several nights I try to finish the game to no avail. But after a while, I got the hang of it and managed to kill the boss. This is the point where I realized that all that time, the game was training me to get better and better.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2012
												Jamestown is just a really great game all around. I am surprised it is Final Form Games's first game; what a debut. It's a vertically-scrolling bullet hell shoot-em-up with a well-presented story, which is about the first colony Jamestown, and it has conquistadors and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Except this Jamestown is on Mars! You play as Sir Walter Raleigh on a spaceship, and what you do is fire all sorts of lasers at all those Spanish Martian ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. There are 4 ships to choose from, with 3 more from a downloadable expansion, and each ship has 2 firing modes. One of my favorite things about this game is local co-op of up two 4 players, all on one computer! You can have one person on mouse, one on keyboard, one on joystick, and one on gamepad, or whatever other alternative input devices. I like the overall feel of this game and the pixelly artstyle and the menus and the music is really outstanding too. There's also a bunch of different difficulties to play on, and bonus levels and lots of  unlockables.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Bullet hell is an understatement. Prepare to have 1000 things on the screen at once all trying to kill you. Its amazing! The controls are tight and every death feels a mistake on the player, not an unfair circumstance. In order to beat the story mode you will have to be able to beat all of the levels of legendary, but the game offers even higher difficulties and challenge modes that will make you cry blood with frustration. The replayability is fantastic.This game is beautiful. The graphics are nostalgic and the artwork does a good job of establishing its own style. The sound is also really good, I found myself getting caught up in the music while playing, it fits the scenario really well.If the gameplay looks appealing to you, then this game is a must buy, very well executed and very fun to play!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This is a brilliantly designed and produced top-down shooter. The retro graphics and soundtrack is charming, the plot melds Victorian-era events with sci-fi and steam punk. The combination makes for a really intriguing mix.This is a skill-based game and the tight controls and unique ship designs/weapon systems will give you countless hours of enjoyment and frustration. If you die, it's probably your fault. Thankfully, the learning curve is handled well i.e. you can't try more difficult levels until you've managed to beat the previous levels at a certain difficulty.This is a relatively short game depending on how good you are able to master the ships and become one with the controls. I find myself favoring the game pad though a keyboard + mouse also works well. Multi-player coop is also quite fun.The charm of this game is that it can also be played in small doses. There was a time that I couldn't beat the final boss. For several nights I try to finish the game to no avail. But after a while, I got the hang of it and managed to kill the boss. This is the point where I realized that all that time, the game was training me to get better and better.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												I'm not great at shmups, but, for maybe the first time in the genre, that wasn't a prequisite for enjoying Jamestown. Perhaps even more unlikely was that a good portion of my enjoyment was due to a shmup's story: Jamestown combines colonial American history with spaceships, Mars, and aliens, then revels in the goofiness of it all. The result, thankfully, isn't B-movie schlock, but rather a charming, cartoonish world where I can feel at home shooting a ton of things and (mostly) avoiding a never-ending stream of bullets. And to that end, Jamestown is also extremely solid. The campaign is a fairly short experience, but there is a real draw to mastering levels on multiple difficulties and -- if you're skillful enough (I wasn't) -- working your way through the myriad one-life, scenario-driven challenge levels.

												A lovably orginal take on bullet hell. Wide variety of difficulties and ships that's sure to bring in people of all skill levels. Works well as both a frantic multiplayer experience and a knuckle grinding single player gauntlet. Just pick a ship you like and start griding away at levels and bosses until you can perfect them, and watch the hours pile up. Also has an amazing score and eye-catching pixel art that perfectly caputres the off-kilter historical themes. Highly reccommended.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												It’s 1619, you’re a guy named Raleigh who’s been busted for your nefarious ways and sentenced to death by the King of England.  You’re not ready to go out like that though; you still have a lot of life in you.  So, you set out for the colonies to make a name for yourself by doing something heroic to put yourself back in the king’s favor.  You set your sights on the lost colony of Roanoke where surely you can become a hero in the war against the Spanish and nab yourself a reprieve on that execution thing.  Except…the colonies, they’re on Mars.  And the Spanish, they fight alongside the Martian Overlords.  And you, you’re going to take them all on with your retro-futuristic wooden sky jet-ski armed with lasers! I know, it sounds nutty right?  It certainly is.  The story plays directly to fans of science fiction though, especially if you’re a fan of things such as “John Carter of Mars”.   Thankfully, this shoot-em-up packs in plenty of action to spice things up and screens full of bullet hell that will keep you on your toes.  The controls are tight enough to make these moments of on screen chaos manageable.   There are times where Jamestown feels like it might be a bit of an easy mode for the classic shmup fan; Raleigh’s hitbox is very tiny and you’ll find yourself getting away with moves that you know shouldn’t be able to.  The game still manages to be a great time though and the story is so far out there, it feels worth pushing through the levels just to find out where they’re going with Sir Raleigh of Mars.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2012
												Jamestown is just a really great game all around. I am surprised it is Final Form Games's first game; what a debut. It's a vertically-scrolling bullet hell shoot-em-up with a well-presented story, which is about the first colony Jamestown, and it has conquistadors and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Except this Jamestown is on Mars! You play as Sir Walter Raleigh on a spaceship, and what you do is fire all sorts of lasers at all those Spanish Martian ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. There are 4 ships to choose from, with 3 more from a downloadable expansion, and each ship has 2 firing modes. One of my favorite things about this game is local co-op of up two 4 players, all on one computer! You can have one person on mouse, one on keyboard, one on joystick, and one on gamepad, or whatever other alternative input devices. I like the overall feel of this game and the pixelly artstyle and the menus and the music is really outstanding too. There's also a bunch of different difficulties to play on, and bonus levels and lots of  unlockables.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												It's a bullet hell. You know it's going to be hard.  But it has some other things going for it.The first couple of difficulty levels will be relatively easier, but it feels more to get played accustomed and prepared for the later difficulties in the game.  It will roll you into the gameplay as to prepare you for harder tasks at later diffficulties.  This will be necessary because later levels will have to be played at harder difficulties, so progression requires harder trials.There is also the fact that you have different ships providing different kind of firepower at you disposal, providing a varying form of gameplay every time you start up a level.  There is also a gauntlet mode later into the game that will provide yourself some replayablity after you beat the levels.However, there is only a local co-op that can support up to 4 players on keyboard, mouse, or controller, and there is a lack of an online multiplayer.  The plot is nothing too intriguing, but it is not a major flaw due to genre.  This game would be put up high on my list of bullet hells, next to Shienryu.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												An interesting title with an awesome pixel art style and a music fitting it. The theme is rididulous but it just makes the game more interesting. Pity the story is sort of average from what I've played. As far as the cutscenes art go, not really my style, but I'm guessing it was an attempt at creating something fitting the story.It isn't as extreme as Ikaruga, which is a plus for me since I can't play on that level. However this game brings out a lot of interesting mechanics I've never seen from the few titles I've played from the genre. You get different ship models each with an interesting superpower which just further engages you without getting to ridiculous missile spam.Now the bad. The levels are short and you quickly get through half the story in about 20 mins. But then it orders you to play all three previous levels again in high difficulty in order to go through. This was a huge disapointment considering I hate replaying games. Overall I recommend it but be prepared to spend quite some time replaying it if you don't go straight Difficult Mode from the start.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2012
												This game was brought to my attention last summer by TotalBiscuit and his WTF Is series. After finally playing through it, I can happily report that this is one of my favorite games of late. I recommend checking out TB's video for an in-depth look at this title, and for a few good laughs at his reactions.Jamestown is sadly a rare event in modern gaming in that it is an inherently difficult game. Fans of the arcade era shmups will feel right at home with this design philosophy. New players to shmups will find an expertly designed and executed game, testing your gaming skills firmly but fairly.Online leaderboards are set up for all game modes, and this gives the game some nice replayability. Add to that varied plane types and play styles, and you can find lots to do with this game that is somewhat absent in voluminous content.Take some time out of being told how great you are with every other game out there and truly test yourself with Jamestown.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												This game is okay.  I'm sorta on the fence about not recommending it, even.  But basically I played it through once and I have no desire to do it again, and that's not good.  It's kiiiiiinda an okay shmup, I guess.  The art style and the music and story are interesting and well done.  But the ship design is just terrible, and shooting things isn't satisfying at all!  How do you ♥♥♥♥ that up?  Do you design a shmup without, like, PLAYING any shmups?  I mean, for Christ's sake, Dodonpachi had better ships and that came out like, what, 20 years ago?  Every ship type Jamestown tries to play with has been done way better in at least one other game already.  Or more like every other shmup out there.  The non-BGM sound design is just... eh.  It's so flat and dull and uninteresting.  Little pew pew noises and dumb, passionless explosions.Granted, it does some interesting things?  Like, people tell me it's better in multiplayer.  Like that means anything.  And it forces you to increase the difficulty or ... you're not allowed to play levels until you replay previous ones on higher ... settings?  Wait, that's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid!  No, no.  No more fence.  Screw this game.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
 4/5. GREAT GAME !  OVERALL This game is super fun and has a nice learning curve, starting with a rather easy shoot 'em up first level and ending with a fifth bullet hell level and one of the hardest and most frustrating end bosses I had encountered, it reminded me to the SNES era, very painful and yet so satisfying once you finally defeat him. It took me around 6h to finish the game, of which 2h were just to clear the final stage... don't judge me. In the end $10 might be a pretty fair price but if you are doubting if you'll like it then wait for a discount and then get it, preparing yourself for the great deed you will have to face to beat this game. REPLAYABILITY The game has various difficulty although if you want to finish it you need to at least complete the final level on Legendary, then you have 2 other difficulties if you are wicked good or really masochist. You also have up to 8 different ships (with the Deluxe Pack) and Gauntlet Mode which allows you to play all the stages with nothing but the 2 credits you get by normally playing a single stage (each credit allows you to endure up to 3 hits). In the end there's plenty to do if you so desire.  GAMEPLAY I played it with my Xbox 360 controller and it played great, using only the left stick and 3 buttons of my controller gave me that classic arcade feel and was really enjoyable, it's pretty easy and fun to play the first 3 levels on normal using the different ships and seeing which is your favorite, then it gets more tricky when you are forced to play on higher difficulties to keep unlocking more stages, however this is for training purposes and it was a design choice by the developer. Regarding that choice I feel it's not ideal for less skillful players such as myself, in the end I did get better and managed to beat the game after a lot of effort though. AESTHETIC I love the look of this game, it's classic arcade shoot' em up visuals and I felt right at home from the times of my childhood and teen years, this games is beautiful to look at and pretty varied with stages that vary quite a lot with a big portfolio of creatures who will attack you in different ways. STORY The story is completely absurd, and it's sorry it's not sorry, you can purchase an alternate script that's even more childish and might give you a little smirk (Plot included on the Deluxe Pack), it's a pretty wild and crazy story that might intend to make fun of other games stories since in the end people play shoot 'em ups to, well, SHOOT F*ing THINGS UP!   MUSIC Now this is an area where this game truly shines, I absolutely loved this game's score, kudos to the composer who just nails it in the head with the epic soundtrack, I still hum the final boss' song in my head when I think about this game (mainly because I suffered that freaking boss a loooot of times).

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												While I’m not a die hard fan of the shootem’ up genre, I do have a fondness for well implemented ones. Ones like Sine Mora had me sinking countless frustrating hours in them but Jamestown was just a bit too much.It’s one thing to have a lot of bullets on screen, that’s kind of the point of the genre, but Jamestown takes this to a very unappealing level by blowing up the size of everything by 100 fold. There were times that during a boss fight I could not even see the background art through all the projectiles. Mechanically this is addressed by making the hitboxes not necessarily like up with the actual art assets, but that does nothing to mitigate the fact that instead of feeling chaotically, mercilessly difficult, Jamestown just ends up feeling hopeless and not worth putting the effort into.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2012
												Jamestown is a western styled shmup that is a cakewalk for the veterans of the genre but acts as a great game to break in newbies to these style of games. There are various challenge modes to unlock via the token system. The challenges range from flying through checkpoints to staying alive as long as possible and offers quite a variety of things to do if you’re bored trying to hit high scores in the campaign. These tokens are also used to unlock various ships to add spice to your gameplay. Jamestown even includes a local multiplayer mode that allows 4 players through additional controller peripherals. The style is surprisingly unique and creative for a genre that was beaten to death by the Japanese for years. Sadly Jamestown has major flaws that makes it less impressive to the shmup elitists. Jamestown bullet patterns are very predictable and lacks variety. Bosses while visually appealing, don’t really carry the super difficulty expected from bosses in hardcore shmups.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												It's a casual (very) shmup, that is okay-ish entry if you are new to the genre, more so if you have a friend avaible for LOCAL co-op, the game doesn't have any form of online play. For more experienced shmup players, I'd recommend passing on this one, if nothing else, you will propably get bad habits from it.The game has it's moments, especially in co-op, but that's about it. Entertainment for a couple hours.Compared to many other shmups avaible, the game doesn't bring anything to the table. The stage design, not to mention the extremely simple and dull boss fights is a big turn off, especially the final stage is flat out horribly designed because "It's the last stage, we must make it totally different and stupid", it feels extremely out of place.Difficulty wise, if you are looking for a challenge, you won't find it until unlocking the "Judgement" difficulty.  There's a huge "false difficulty" ramp in the game when starting, simply because the background has alot of distracting factors in it, after you get used to the art style, the game is a cakewalk if you have ever played any other shmups. A few of the challenge missions were rather fun, altho not that difficult when you get the idea for each one.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
												Jamestown is one of the strongest 'against-the-flow' feelings i've had against a game; here is this clearly beautifully crafted thing that for some reason i can't enjoy or appreciate. Everyone says it's great, the reviews do too--so why don't i like it?Jamestown is, in my mind, not a schmup designed to be a schmup. The rudimentary gameplay is not interesting or challenging enough to sustain prolonged interest, the enemy types are forgettable, the stages are bland and mono-paced, and the same song plays for every level, minus the last--an unforgiveable sin, to my mind, in this genre where ZUN and so many others have set such a precedent and high standard of quality for soundtrack composition. Everyone says this soundtrack is great, and i disagree--it is orchestral, emotionaless, unintuitive, and not at all designed around the experience of FLYING A SHIP SHOOTING STUFF. At the end of the day, Jamestown feels like an experience not designed around itself--the fluff is what makes the gameplay, but the fluff is stupid (no, it's /really/ stupid), and i don't like it and you can't make me like it, and therefore the game doesn't hold much weight by itself. The 'Vaunt' system is kind of cool, but ZUN's done better in every Touhou from 8 onward, so that's not much to brag about.Anyway. If you think there's a chance you'd enjoy a mediocre shooting experience with an impersonal movie soundtrack and terrible writing, buy Jamestown. i feel i was tricked. this review is brutally honest. i apologize for anyone's feelings that it hurts.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												While the artwork and game setting are very well thought out and portrayed, the longevity of Jamestown is its downfall. There are five campaign levels that must be beaten in Legendary difficulty in order for the player to advance. This difficulty level is appropriate for the first four levels, but on the fifth and final level, this design choice becomes a problem and a hindrance. The last level is so difficult, I consider it to be poorly designed and most importantly, inadequate. It is as if the designers realized they did not have much of a game in their hands, and decided to make the final fifth level nearly unbeatable, in order to excuse the amount of time necessary to complete the campaign. Sure, there are bonus modes/levels to be unlocked, but they are merely side distractions, that do not provide the player with additional entertainment or value. Jamestown is simply too short, in addition to one of its five levels being extremely poor. To add to this insult, the developers have released an expensive DLC for an already overpriced base game, that adds very little. The limited amount of continues is also another bad design choice because of the terrible last level. In the end, the player is left with a clear understanding that the developers resorted to a cheap and unimaginative means of prolonging Jamestown's lifespan by making it artificially and unusually difficult in the last level. Through this, it is very quick to realize that this game does not involve much, and the developers should be ashamed of themselves for charging so much for so little content. There are innumerable amounts of games of this same genre that are incomparably better, and most are more than 20 years older. Jamestown is a prime example of independent developers taking advantage of the scene and overcharging consumers for content that is extremely scarce, poorly implemented, and quite limited. There is very little to do, very little to experience, and very little to enjoy. Jamestown can be beaten in less than one hour, and there are many other games that have a much better value than this. What a waste.Jamestown is mediocre.

number of helpful: 7 of 21 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Jamestown: Legend Of The Lost Colony is a neo-classical top-down shooter for up to 4 players, set on 17th-century British Colonial Mars. It features all the intensity, depth, and lovingly handcrafted pixels of a classic arcade shooter, with a modern twist: deeply-integrated cooperative gameplay.Unlike most top-down shooters, which give multiple players a shared pool of lives or continues, Jamestown does something different. So long as any player survives, the team can be brought back from death. By giving every player the power to rescue their team from the jaws of destruction, Jamestown creates an exhilarating cooperative experience where everyone’s contribution truly matters. Win or lose, your team will do it together.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												An extremely enjoyable bullet hell game with features such as:4 player coop with additional mice, keyboards and gamepads (and an easy controls setup)5 Chapters/Levels with up to 5 difficulties for varying degrees of skill4 (7 with the DLC) different ships with very unique playstylesBonus Levels with varying objectives (also support 1-4 players)The pixel art may not be to everyone's liking but I liked its distinctive direction for gameplay purposes and story scenes.Bonus Levels, Ships and additional content such as gamemodes are tied in with a nice and steady progression system based on coins you get when finishing levels (the higher the difficulty, the more coins).It's a lot of fun with friends yet still addicting playing it solo.Jamestown was my first entry into bullet hell territory; the learning curve is nice and the gameplay simple yet hard to master. I definitely recommend Jamestown to anyone slightly interested in bullet hell games, you won't regret it (wait for a sale and get the DLC if you want the additional 3 ships, I enjoy them as much as vanilla ones).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 11, 2013
												Jamestown was my gateway drug into the world of shmups (shoot 'em ups). It's greatest asset is not its gloriously rendered pixel graphics, unique art design, tight controls, solid gameplay mechanics, stellar cooperative play, excellent support for a number of control peripherals, or soundtrack of better quality than that of the best triple-A productions. What really makes this game one of the best of its kind is its ability to constantly encourage the player to improve their skill, avoiding frustrating difficulty cliffs, and creating a degree of replay value rarely seen in titles of any genre. The only gripe I have is the lack of online multiplayer, which is easily forgiven given the incredible quality of the whole package. There is no reason for anyone to pass this up. Do yourself the favor.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Jamestown is a shmup that's really worth getting.  My favorite is gauntlet mode, which is a decent approximation of a true arcade mode.  To get a grip on the scoring mechanics, try the score-based challenges and pay attention to what an enemy is doing when you destroy them and how it effects the bonus items (think of challenges more as scoring tutorials).There are multiple ships that really do play differently, and the levels have a lot of variety in them.  Four-player simultaneous play is an interesting bonus, but don't worry the game plays fine with just one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2011
												Awesome 2d scrolling shooter/shmup. The art's pretty good and the old west theme works well. If you haven't heard of bullet hell or danmaku games, here's a good game to get acquainted with the genre. The basic premise is there's lots of bullets on screen and your ship's hitbox is a small circle in the center, which allows you to squeeze through bullet patterns. The scoring system is based on item collection chaining.You have 4 ships to select from, with different main and special weapons. In addition, you have a "Vaunt" ability, which gives you a temporary shield on use, and 2x strength and points until the meter runs out. You can keep the meter going by grabbing gold that enemies drop, and the longer you keep it going, the more points you get once it runs out. If you need to live a little longer, you can Vaunt again, giving another shield but a smaller bonus.There are 5 levels and 20 challenge levels, which makes the game perfect for both long sessions and quick bursts.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2011
												I love the art style of this game.  The campaign itself is really short, only 6 missions. But there is a lot of additional stuff that can be done after you finish.  The Co-Op is a little misleading.  No, there is no online co-op. No, there is no LAN co-op. I was very disappointed by this because on Steam it says "Local Co-Op".  The only way this game can be played co-op is if someone is using the mouse, and the 2nd person is using the arrow keys. But even worse, it has 4-player co-op. Which means the 3rd person has to use WASD keys, and 4th person has to use a controller.  I think it's completely stupid the way they implemented co-op, even for an indie developer.This has no bearing on playing the game as a single player experience.  It was a solid fun gaming experience, and if you keep in mind to not be expecting anything more than a 1 - 2 hour story, then I suppose you should pick this game up.

This can be considered a "bullet-hell" shooter, based on how fast the difficulty increases as you progress through the game. Judgement, the hardest difficulty, is only for those who are experts of these kind of shooters. Very addictive, simple gameplay, with a story that does not get in the way, music that is very epic sounding, and set pieces and levels that look very well-done and retro feeling, this game is worth a look.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A bullet-hell game. Normally, most people just hear the words and move away from anything related to the genre. But Jamestown is easily an exception to that instinctive behaviour.If you're old enough to remember those games where you had a plane or a ship flying on a vertically-scrolling background and tanks/turrets/monsters/something evil appeared and lobbed a red ball of death towards your vessel, Jamestown doesn't fall very far from that tree. What you need to know is that, much like most of those games, enemies spawn at the exact same place every time you run the exact same level (that is, the level itself associated with a difficulty). Unlike those games, however, you get the chance to select the difficulty.Jamestown is nice enough to players new to the bullet-hell genre by having multiple difficulties. "How is that nice?" you're thinking. The easiest difficulty is easy enough for someone that never played any game in his life to learn patterns, which in turn make them develop a sense of where to be and where not to be given the properties of the ship they're using. And each step in the difficulty curve is acceptable at the point where the player can reliably clear a level without dying more than once; it's a proof of skill from the player's part. That said, most people won't be able to clear all levels at the highest difficulty the game offers, and possibly not even the one before that. If you're in it for the "100%", you better be prepared to invest a good time of your life here.But achievement nuts aside, Jamestown is full of strong points. The controls are responsive as you'd expect a game of the genre, the music is like someone tossed you a thousand dollars and said "keep it, no strings attached", the visual style is undoubitably gorgeous. It even has an unusual backstory in a strange futuristic-pastlike-future for a game with no reason to have a story, if you care about those things. It also has a sort of "challenge mode" where you try to complete hard tasks in a preset course; think of it as this game's minigames. You have an activatable invulnerability shield on certain conditions as a base game mechanic related to scoring points. You also get to have four different ships to blast the baddies, each very different in gameplay from the others, so you can specialize in one that best suits you or try to master all of them for added replayability. And of course, you have a "gauntlet mode" where even reaching its end is like getting a free pat in the back and a bucket of your favourite drink.If you're looking for weak points, the only things that come to mind is the extra ships dlc (because you either love them and use them or end up sticking to only one or non-at-all since you already love one of the base game's ships) and the inherent what-you-see-is-what-you-get replayability that's associated with fixed levels and how high the skill barrier is for you. If you're a master of the bullet-hell genre, the hardest difficulty may be less challenging than you'd hope.Also, one can not stress this enough: the music of this game is amazing. The soundtrack's extra cost? If you play the game and like it, I recommend you buy it to hear it outside the game; supposedly the money goes to the composer, which needs to eat just like you.All in all, Jamestown is a great game. A solid 8 out of 10 easily, maybe even more. If you consider the game a little costy, wait for a discount; if the music is also at a discount, make sure you also buy it if you liked it in-game. As for the dlc ships, hit or miss: if you like the game, and want to say you like the people that put their heart making it, buy; otherwise my opinion is avoid unless at a good discount.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 5, 2011
												There aren't many bullet hell games on Steam or on the PC in general, but this one is a great inclusion in the genre. In general, bullet hell games can be impossibly frustrating right from the start, but with 5 different diffuculty settings, this game can really be picked up and enjoyed by players of all skill levels. Each step up in difficulty is not a huge leap, so its refreshing finding yourself finally challenging a level on a higher difficulty. That said, the single player campaign is incredibly short (as is the case with most shumps), but you'll find yourself coming back again and again trying to finally beat that last level or running through one of the challenge levels. It's a great pick up if you're a fan of shumps or if you can grab it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 26, 2011
												So you’ve never played a Bullet Hell shooter before and ‘Jamestown’ got your attention just because you’re a sucker for a nice alternative reality and/or Steampunk setting? Then let ‘Jamestown’ be your starter drug!It’s hard -- hell, it’s called “Bullet HELL” for a reason -- and you’ll curse many, many, many times, but you WILL [have to] get better progressing through the levels, and playing the first level again on one of the lower difficulties after beating the last level, you’ll somehow manage it without using all your credits. Who’d have thought?There are only five campaign levels, but its 20-odd bonus challenges [again, “challenges” for a reason] and, of course, the Gauntlet will test your skills to the fullest.Thanks to its retro-graphics and magnificent score, the game looks and sounds simply amazing. Beware though: Keyboard and mouse control are a bit odd. Gamepad recommended.

												Pretty awesome flying shooter game.  I rarely play "shumps" but this one looked pretty cool and I was impressed.  Each level and ship is drastically different in style, graphics, and type of baddies.  My only gripe is that its short --- It took me 75 mins to beat the first 3 levels on normal, then the first 4 levels on difficult, then all 5 levels on legendary.  The game only has 5 levels, Just start on legendary since you cannot proceed further into the game unless you beat the earlier levels on legendary.  It appears to be a 4 player coop... I'd love to play it coop but I don't have anyone else that owns it.  It has roughly 6-7 difficulty levels so it can be replayed a lot.  It also has about 20 short challenge levels, roughly 60 seconds each.  Worth it at a discount.

Posted: July 12, 2011
												This is one of the most amazingly polished indie games i've ever played. This is immediately noticeable if you're using a controller to navigate the menus. I was put off by the description of this game, but I ended up playing it anyways. It's a beautiful game from the story art, to the level graphics. The screenshots and videos do not do this game justice. There is a sort of mangled historically-warped story to the game that is also interesting. It's easy to play, giving you lots of deaths before you actually fail the level. Even when you fail, you still collect credits meaning you still inch your way towards buying a different ship. Much of the replay seems to be in forcing you to replay previous levels on a harder difficulty, but it's not so bad. My only gripe with the game is the lack of sound effects from enemies; they only play sounds when they take damage or die, never when they fire. It gives a sort of flat feeling to the gameplay.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Jamestown is a classic arcade vertical shooter, but with a feeling that's just impossible to describe. The story interjects between levels and feels like it came straight from the diary of a colonial American, if a colonial American were ever involved in a war against Martians; yeah, the story is strange.The game isn't bullet hell, but sometimes it feels close. There'll be plenty of moments leaving you tensing up as you swerve to dodge a volley of shots, and a lot of edge-of-your-seat boss battles. The music helps too; every track is listen-worthy outside the game and each song gets the heart racing-- a word to describe the music is "Epic".My only complaint is it's damned short. A shump veteran can finish Jamestown in one sitting. However for the price, it's worth it. And there's also challenge modes and multiplayer once you've saved the world in the story-proper.

												Jamestown is a good bullet-hell game if you like the genre and want a challenge. There are different scenes on a map that you have to defeat, and you have to defeat the previous scenes on harder difficulties consequtively to unlock the next areas. All the while, you gain gold which you use to buy content, such as new ships, different challenges, and different difficulties. Overall the game looks great and has the retro feel from the arcades of the 90's. Good western style adventure music, and lovecraftian-victorian-western settings and style really makes it an interseting twist. Bullet-hell, shooter with tentacles in the wild west of mars? Yes please!Make sure you're using a controller and not trying to use the keyboard. This game demands a joystick!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												I'll admit, I completely overlooked Jamestown at first. I can't remember why, but I'm sorry I did, and I thank Steam's christmas objectives for making me get it, because it's an amazing little game. The originality of it's premise (Sir Walter Raleigh and company ON MARS!) it's lovingly hand-drawn art and sprites, challenging gameplay and amazing soundtrack combine to create a truly excellent experience. In a time where so few games are even deserving to be called such rather then pointless wastes of time, boring grindfests or immersions in human aggression and stupidity, Jamestown invites you away from all that and takes you back on a wonderous, if brief journey to the golden age of gaming.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												This game is great on a variety of ways:+ Very responsive controls: runs fast on pretty much any rig nowadays @60 Hertz+ Very polished game: Both the tech and art managed to deliver an all around solid package. Major props for the small team+ Attractive visuals and music. The plot and campaign back story are nice additions+ Game is short but challenging. Offers a good range of difficulty levels. Divine mode is certainly nerve wrecking for most people but I personally find it manageable. Can't say the same about Judgement difficulty (the hardest setting).+ Co-op is pretty neat! A shame it is not online, though+ Overall bosses, enemies placement and design and bullet patterns are well distributed across the levels+ The final chapter is a very intriguing level. The boss fight feels great+ Bonus challenges are intriguing- Interesting ship concepts add a bit on the multiplayer field, but I don't find them very fun, really. Hence if you plan for mostly single player gaming, I do not recommend the DLC.I tapped out on the last difficulty setting (Judgement), which is quite brutal.Nonetheless, if you want to play an entry level bullet hell either solo or co-op, do play Jamestown! Also, if you are a seasoned player make sure you get to test your skills and scores on both Judgement difficulty and Gauntlet mode.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Recently beat this game (all 5 stages offered) over the course of several hours. Being a big schmup fan, I could not resist purchasing this game when it was on a Steam sale. Having played quite a few schmup games (Gradius V, Raystorm/Crisis, Darius Burst, Ikaruga, Bug Princess, DonDonPachi), I went into this expecting a good time in bullet-hell.... but had gotten only about 60% of what I had expected. Was not "blown-away," per say. The player hit-box did not appear to have issues, but the gameplay itself felt slightly lacking. Was a bit turned off at the fact that you have to "unlock stages" in a range of difficulties in order to play them. It felt like a cheap way to reduce the enemy/difficulty programming of the 5 stages.  The bosses also (even on harder difficulties) do feel a bit too easy to beat. 3.5 of 5 stars if you want to enjoy a decent schmup game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												This game is great on a variety of ways:+ Very responsive controls: runs fast on pretty much any rig nowadays @60 Hertz+ Very polished game: Both the tech and art managed to deliver an all around solid package. Major props for the small team+ Attractive visuals and music. The plot and campaign back story are nice additions+ Game is short but challenging. Offers a good range of difficulty levels. Divine mode is certainly nerve wrecking for most people but I personally find it manageable. Can't say the same about Judgement difficulty (the hardest setting).+ Co-op is pretty neat! A shame it is not online, though+ Overall bosses, enemies placement and design and bullet patterns are well distributed across the levels+ The final chapter is a very intriguing level. The boss fight feels great+ Bonus challenges are intriguing- Interesting ship concepts add a bit on the multiplayer field, but I don't find them very fun, really. Hence if you plan for mostly single player gaming, I do not recommend the DLC.I tapped out on the last difficulty setting (Judgement), which is quite brutal.Nonetheless, if you want to play an entry level bullet hell either solo or co-op, do play Jamestown! Also, if you are a seasoned player make sure you get to test your skills and scores on both Judgement difficulty and Gauntlet mode.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2011
												I love the art style of this game.  The campaign itself is really short, only 6 missions. But there is a lot of additional stuff that can be done after you finish.  The Co-Op is a little misleading.  No, there is no online co-op. No, there is no LAN co-op. I was very disappointed by this because on Steam it says "Local Co-Op".  The only way this game can be played co-op is if someone is using the mouse, and the 2nd person is using the arrow keys. But even worse, it has 4-player co-op. Which means the 3rd person has to use WASD keys, and 4th person has to use a controller.  I think it's completely stupid the way they implemented co-op, even for an indie developer.This has no bearing on playing the game as a single player experience.  It was a solid fun gaming experience, and if you keep in mind to not be expecting anything more than a 1 - 2 hour story, then I suppose you should pick this game up.
