												Don't be turned off by the lack of amazing graphics or seemingly repetitive gameplay. The music is fantastic and the game has a lot of replay value due to the unlockable ships and difficulty levels. Although online co-op is lacking, having friends play next to you is still worth it. The story itself is short, but the message it carries across is touching. As for gameplay, it's challenging and fun, even if at times it can make you angry at the multitude of projectiles on the screen. It's well made and deserves a solid place in anyone's gaming library. In all, I recommend at least one playthrough, even if you aren't a fan of this genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Don't let my scant amount of time fool you. I've played this game a lot on the console version and I intend to as well with this one on Steam. There's a lot of Shmups here on Steam, a lot of damn fine ones. Some are bullet hell shooters that test your vision and agility, others are straight up fragfests that just allow a lot of fun and are kind of forgiving. This game falls somewhere in between, which is perhaps the best part about it.I've been playing Shmups since the Gradius/Lifeforce days on the NES or R-Type on the SMS so I'm well versed in them but seeing as how I'm 32 now, I'm nowhere near as skilled as I once was. This is one of the few I can remember that gets me as excited as those used to. It's got that amazingly attractive Metal Slug/Neo-Geo era arcade graphical and musical style that draws you in and makes you feel like you're popping $10 worth of quarters into the machine just to beat two levels again. It's not only beautifully designed, but it also contains one of the most imaginative visions of a sci-fi world I've ever seen. Where every other Shmup follows the "Oh noes! There are aliens coming from Dimension X and only you in the prototype YXZ fighter can defeat the intergalactic hoards!" formula, this game stretches it a bit further with it's alternate reality, colonization-of-Mars instead of America take. It makes for levels you haven't seen before and attains that rare quality most Shmups outside Metal Slug fail to grasp. The replayability is great too. The mechanic that draws you to play more is through the acquisition of cash at the end of levels which is then used in the game store to unlock new ships, weapons, levels, and game modes. It is a great method to get you to replay the 10 or so levels over and over and over. It's also one of the few Shmups where I'm actually capable of completing higher difficulties because the game does a fair job of ramping it up. It doesn't just throw you into Dark Souls: Shmup Edition.If you love Shmups, this is honestly my favorite so far on Steam and I've played almost all of them. And do yourself a favor, get the edition with the soundtrack. It's one of the best freakin' soundtracks I've ever heard in a game.

												An addicting SHMUP game set in an alternate timeline where English Settlements were built on mars. The gameplay is classic bullet-hell chaos, with a multitude of different control options.  You can choose from four unique ships to battle a large cast of enemies and bosses.The games has a fair learning curve by requiring you to beat earlier levels on higher difficulties to unlock the later challenges. There are also plenty of extra challenges to keep you entertained. The graphics have a polished retro look, and the music is fantastic. Seriously, this is one of those games worth it for the music alone. Great soundtrack! The game also sports up to four player local co op, which is as fun as it is hectic. So buy this! One of the best modern SHMUPS out!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												I am not a fan of the bullet hell genre. I AM a fan of Jamestown. Unlike when playing other bullet hell shmups, I never felt like Jamestown was difficult for the sake of difficulty or taunting my failure to finish a level in some ultra-niche genre. Instead, the Vaunt mechanism, the level design, and the overall tone of the game always seemed to suggest, "You can do it! Try again!" The risk/reward design philosophy behind Vaunt is simple yet brilliant, allowing players to focus on survival or gaining points or a balance between. Perhaps most importantly, the game just /feels/ good to play. Few modern games are this much fun. And don't let the lack of online co-op dissuade you; the single-player experience is fantastic, replay value is great, and the game truly shines when you get one, two, or three friends to play with you on the same screen. There's nothing quite like the rush of victory when you and two buddies narrowly clear a level on Divine difficulty after the third or fourth try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Well...the screenshots and trailer actually give you exactly what the game is about: a bullet hell shooter with a nice art style and beautiful music. It has a story element that you can simply forget about (so Mars is colonized in the medieval ages by the British, and they're at war with the spanish? Okay...nevermind. Just let me shoot some robots), an ingame shop  to unlock things (levels and ships mostly; not ship upgrades or levels) and...erm...well, that's it, really. Each ship has 2 firing methods; the 2nd one is more powerfull but slows you down.The thing is as arcade-ish as arcade gets: 3 credits with 3 lives each level. Better survive on that, because there is no way around it (lose everything, then you'll have to restart the entire level). The only power-up/mechanic in the game is gold that, once the meter is filled, makes you invisible for a few seconds.Keep in mind that this game has only 6 levels. Note that since they're all very beautiful and challenging, that many difficulties and bonus content really stretches this out, but you have to take this into account.Also...not sure if I'm the only one, but I just cannot get this game to look normal on fullscreen (1920x1080, win 8.1). Since this is the kind of game you really can't look away from your own ship, it doesn't matter as much, but still...meh. :-\Still...I prefer a short but very enjoyable game over a long stretched out one. It's not expensive yet does exactly what promised: frantic, frustrating-in-a-good-way action. So: recommended. :-)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												Jamestown is a classic arcade vertical shooter, but with a feeling that's just impossible to describe. The story interjects between levels and feels like it came straight from the diary of a colonial American, if a colonial American were ever involved in a war against Martians; yeah, the story is strange.The game isn't bullet hell, but sometimes it feels close. There'll be plenty of moments leaving you tensing up as you swerve to dodge a volley of shots, and a lot of edge-of-your-seat boss battles. The music helps too; every track is listen-worthy outside the game and each song gets the heart racing-- a word to describe the music is "Epic".My only complaint is it's damned short. A shump veteran can finish Jamestown in one sitting. However for the price, it's worth it. And there's also challenge modes and multiplayer once you've saved the world in the story-proper.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Recently beat this game (all 5 stages offered) over the course of several hours. Being a big schmup fan, I could not resist purchasing this game when it was on a Steam sale. Having played quite a few schmup games (Gradius V, Raystorm/Crisis, Darius Burst, Ikaruga, Bug Princess, DonDonPachi), I went into this expecting a good time in bullet-hell.... but had gotten only about 60% of what I had expected. Was not "blown-away," per say. The player hit-box did not appear to have issues, but the gameplay itself felt slightly lacking. Was a bit turned off at the fact that you have to "unlock stages" in a range of difficulties in order to play them. It felt like a cheap way to reduce the enemy/difficulty programming of the 5 stages.  The bosses also (even on harder difficulties) do feel a bit too easy to beat. 3.5 of 5 stars if you want to enjoy a decent schmup game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												Don't let my scant amount of time fool you. I've played this game a lot on the console version and I intend to as well with this one on Steam. There's a lot of Shmups here on Steam, a lot of damn fine ones. Some are bullet hell shooters that test your vision and agility, others are straight up fragfests that just allow a lot of fun and are kind of forgiving. This game falls somewhere in between, which is perhaps the best part about it.I've been playing Shmups since the Gradius/Lifeforce days on the NES or R-Type on the SMS so I'm well versed in them but seeing as how I'm 32 now, I'm nowhere near as skilled as I once was. This is one of the few I can remember that gets me as excited as those used to. It's got that amazingly attractive Metal Slug/Neo-Geo era arcade graphical and musical style that draws you in and makes you feel like you're popping $10 worth of quarters into the machine just to beat two levels again. It's not only beautifully designed, but it also contains one of the most imaginative visions of a sci-fi world I've ever seen. Where every other Shmup follows the "Oh noes! There are aliens coming from Dimension X and only you in the prototype YXZ fighter can defeat the intergalactic hoards!" formula, this game stretches it a bit further with it's alternate reality, colonization-of-Mars instead of America take. It makes for levels you haven't seen before and attains that rare quality most Shmups outside Metal Slug fail to grasp. The replayability is great too. The mechanic that draws you to play more is through the acquisition of cash at the end of levels which is then used in the game store to unlock new ships, weapons, levels, and game modes. It is a great method to get you to replay the 10 or so levels over and over and over. It's also one of the few Shmups where I'm actually capable of completing higher difficulties because the game does a fair job of ramping it up. It doesn't just throw you into Dark Souls: Shmup Edition.If you love Shmups, this is honestly my favorite so far on Steam and I've played almost all of them. And do yourself a favor, get the edition with the soundtrack. It's one of the best freakin' soundtracks I've ever heard in a game.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												One of the first shmups on Steam, Jamestown is definitely one of the better ones on Steam as well. The game has rather simple patterns along with an equally simple scoring system. But at the same time it is also quite fast paced and there are a LOT of stray bullets. I usually enjoy the slower, more bullet-dense type of shmup but this one definitely struck a chord with me regardless. Game has good art, good music.... it's a small game in scope, but everything it does it does right. The only disappointments are the lack of Steam Cloud in a game with unlocks (wasn't around at the time and never added), and that the co-op brazenly advertised in the trailer is local only. The latter is a real shame; I've played it in person with friends and it was a really enjoyable experience.

												An addicting SHMUP game set in an alternate timeline where English Settlements were built on mars. The gameplay is classic bullet-hell chaos, with a multitude of different control options.  You can choose from four unique ships to battle a large cast of enemies and bosses.The games has a fair learning curve by requiring you to beat earlier levels on higher difficulties to unlock the later challenges. There are also plenty of extra challenges to keep you entertained. The graphics have a polished retro look, and the music is fantastic. Seriously, this is one of those games worth it for the music alone. Great soundtrack! The game also sports up to four player local co op, which is as fun as it is hectic. So buy this! One of the best modern SHMUPS out!

												I threw my life away on arcade shmups like this when I was ten. If you love intense games, particularly shmups, you'll be at home, here. The artstyle, poesy of the storytelling, and particularly the music, give this game an atmosphere that's akin to Wind Waker (think pirates, terrifying sea creatures, and a general buccaneering vibe). Also, the taut little propaghanda-esque quips before each level are great and get you psyched like no "SO POWER WORKOUT PLAYLIST" can. Everyone should play this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												An extremely enjoyable bullet hell game with features such as:4 player coop with additional mice, keyboards and gamepads (and an easy controls setup)5 Chapters/Levels with up to 5 difficulties for varying degrees of skill4 (7 with the DLC) different ships with very unique playstylesBonus Levels with varying objectives (also support 1-4 players)The pixel art may not be to everyone's liking but I liked its distinctive direction for gameplay purposes and story scenes.Bonus Levels, Ships and additional content such as gamemodes are tied in with a nice and steady progression system based on coins you get when finishing levels (the higher the difficulty, the more coins).It's a lot of fun with friends yet still addicting playing it solo.Jamestown was my first entry into bullet hell territory; the learning curve is nice and the gameplay simple yet hard to master. I definitely recommend Jamestown to anyone slightly interested in bullet hell games, you won't regret it (wait for a sale and get the DLC if you want the additional 3 ships, I enjoy them as much as vanilla ones).

												A fun and challenging 2D scrolling shooter with a fantastic visual flair.I'll admit, I'm pretty biased. I love 2D scrolling shooter titles. That said, this is one of the more visually interesting and enjoyable ones I have come across in recent memory.The challenge is definitely there, but unlike some of the more notorious games in this genre, this one is at least not so frustrating that you can't hardly even enjoy it.The difficulty ramps up as you go along and unlock new stages, and it eventually shoehorns you into playing on the higher difficulty levels if you want to finish the game properly, but even if you have a hard time with these types of games, you'll at least be able to enjoy the earlier stages well enough for this one to be worth your time.A wonky yet refreshingly strange concept of a story helps bring some creativity to the title, and the ships and powerups are varied enough to make the mechanics feel fresh and interesting between each choice.

												I love the art style of this game.  The campaign itself is really short, only 6 missions. But there is a lot of additional stuff that can be done after you finish.  The Co-Op is a little misleading.  No, there is no online co-op. No, there is no LAN co-op. I was very disappointed by this because on Steam it says "Local Co-Op".  The only way this game can be played co-op is if someone is using the mouse, and the 2nd person is using the arrow keys. But even worse, it has 4-player co-op. Which means the 3rd person has to use WASD keys, and 4th person has to use a controller.  I think it's completely stupid the way they implemented co-op, even for an indie developer.This has no bearing on playing the game as a single player experience.  It was a solid fun gaming experience, and if you keep in mind to not be expecting anything more than a 1 - 2 hour story, then I suppose you should pick this game up.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A bullet-hell game. Normally, most people just hear the words and move away from anything related to the genre. But Jamestown is easily an exception to that instinctive behaviour.If you're old enough to remember those games where you had a plane or a ship flying on a vertically-scrolling background and tanks/turrets/monsters/something evil appeared and lobbed a red ball of death towards your vessel, Jamestown doesn't fall very far from that tree. What you need to know is that, much like most of those games, enemies spawn at the exact same place every time you run the exact same level (that is, the level itself associated with a difficulty). Unlike those games, however, you get the chance to select the difficulty.Jamestown is nice enough to players new to the bullet-hell genre by having multiple difficulties. "How is that nice?" you're thinking. The easiest difficulty is easy enough for someone that never played any game in his life to learn patterns, which in turn make them develop a sense of where to be and where not to be given the properties of the ship they're using. And each step in the difficulty curve is acceptable at the point where the player can reliably clear a level without dying more than once; it's a proof of skill from the player's part. That said, most people won't be able to clear all levels at the highest difficulty the game offers, and possibly not even the one before that. If you're in it for the "100%", you better be prepared to invest a good time of your life here.But achievement nuts aside, Jamestown is full of strong points. The controls are responsive as you'd expect a game of the genre, the music is like someone tossed you a thousand dollars and said "keep it, no strings attached", the visual style is undoubitably gorgeous. It even has an unusual backstory in a strange futuristic-pastlike-future for a game with no reason to have a story, if you care about those things. It also has a sort of "challenge mode" where you try to complete hard tasks in a preset course; think of it as this game's minigames. You have an activatable invulnerability shield on certain conditions as a base game mechanic related to scoring points. You also get to have four different ships to blast the baddies, each very different in gameplay from the others, so you can specialize in one that best suits you or try to master all of them for added replayability. And of course, you have a "gauntlet mode" where even reaching its end is like getting a free pat in the back and a bucket of your favourite drink.If you're looking for weak points, the only things that come to mind is the extra ships dlc (because you either love them and use them or end up sticking to only one or non-at-all since you already love one of the base game's ships) and the inherent what-you-see-is-what-you-get replayability that's associated with fixed levels and how high the skill barrier is for you. If you're a master of the bullet-hell genre, the hardest difficulty may be less challenging than you'd hope.Also, one can not stress this enough: the music of this game is amazing. The soundtrack's extra cost? If you play the game and like it, I recommend you buy it to hear it outside the game; supposedly the money goes to the composer, which needs to eat just like you.All in all, Jamestown is a great game. A solid 8 out of 10 easily, maybe even more. If you consider the game a little costy, wait for a discount; if the music is also at a discount, make sure you also buy it if you liked it in-game. As for the dlc ships, hit or miss: if you like the game, and want to say you like the people that put their heart making it, buy; otherwise my opinion is avoid unless at a good discount.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Jamestown is a shmup that's really worth getting.  My favorite is gauntlet mode, which is a decent approximation of a true arcade mode.  To get a grip on the scoring mechanics, try the score-based challenges and pay attention to what an enemy is doing when you destroy them and how it effects the bonus items (think of challenges more as scoring tutorials).There are multiple ships that really do play differently, and the levels have a lot of variety in them.  Four-player simultaneous play is an interesting bonus, but don't worry the game plays fine with just one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 11, 2013
												Jamestown was my gateway drug into the world of shmups (shoot 'em ups). It's greatest asset is not its gloriously rendered pixel graphics, unique art design, tight controls, solid gameplay mechanics, stellar cooperative play, excellent support for a number of control peripherals, or soundtrack of better quality than that of the best triple-A productions. What really makes this game one of the best of its kind is its ability to constantly encourage the player to improve their skill, avoiding frustrating difficulty cliffs, and creating a degree of replay value rarely seen in titles of any genre. The only gripe I have is the lack of online multiplayer, which is easily forgiven given the incredible quality of the whole package. There is no reason for anyone to pass this up. Do yourself the favor.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2011
												A very interesting game. Take Touhou, for the patterns, the small hitbox, the cherry border, and the general feeling, and mix it to metal slug's graphism, and you have Jamestown.Overall, it's a really fun game, with pvery good graphisms. Besides, you can play with 3 people on the same PC, so you better have a decent screen.Now for the cons:-compared to other bullet hell games, this game is too easy. You have 2 lives, and 2 coninues PER STAGE. There's a level-run option, but it's locked when you begin. Also, bosses are ridiculous easy, even the last one, I cleared him losing only one life.-also, the multiplayer seems quite interesting, but you can't play on teh Internet! If you want to try multiplayer, you have to bring your friends at home IRL! It's like a console on a PC!I dig hard to find those cons, because this game isn't really expensive, so it's unfair from me to be like that. It's a really good game, and I suggest you to try it. It's easy, you'll see.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												One of the first shmups on Steam, Jamestown is definitely one of the better ones on Steam as well. The game has rather simple patterns along with an equally simple scoring system. But at the same time it is also quite fast paced and there are a LOT of stray bullets. I usually enjoy the slower, more bullet-dense type of shmup but this one definitely struck a chord with me regardless. Game has good art, good music.... it's a small game in scope, but everything it does it does right. The only disappointments are the lack of Steam Cloud in a game with unlocks (wasn't around at the time and never added), and that the co-op brazenly advertised in the trailer is local only. The latter is a real shame; I've played it in person with friends and it was a really enjoyable experience.
